poem:
**Curtain Call**

The ghosts of playwrights linger  
in dusty auctions, where  
gavel-strikes echo like  
fading applause. Osborne's collection,  
a spectral cast, cries backstage,  
dreaming of a public encore,  
while private hands  
clasp each memory away,  
leaving us to wonder  
what if the archives  
kept the stories alive.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Too much theatre memorabilia is being lost to private collectors, says David Hare The vital memorabilia and personal effects of our greatest playwrights should be secured in a reinvigorated national theatre collection, according to David Hare, who said too many were going into private hands. Hundreds of pieces from the playwright John Osborne’s collection are going up for auction on Wednesday evening, with the proceeds used to support the Avron Foundation, which bought his house". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
